ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A better understanding of what it meant to be an efficient leader. From examples of in-fleet scenarios, to advice from experienced officers, we were able to get a variety of leadership examples and methods that would help us develop as future leaders in the military.
I learned the main difference between leadership and management, and how to use that in daily life.
This is a required Naval ROTC course.

I had a lot of practice with public speaking and developing my presentation skills. This class forced us to stand up in front of the class and present certain topics. I also learned specific things about developing as a leader.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It's strengths we tied to the amount of interaction involved with the course, from public speeches to student led seminars, we were able to contribute a lot to the course. It's major weakness would come from the obvious fact that we aren't given a Yale course credit, as well as some of the seminars being done more in the name of "we have to do this," rather than, "we should be doing this."

Pros: Low course-load, super-chill instructor (CDR Lanzer), easy material given, required if you are in navy ROTC cons: Meets early in the morning (730-845), lectures can often be quite dry. Unfortunately, this is not the fault of the instructor, but of the navy-required way of teaching.

This class has no weaknesses to note. This is an ROTC required class and the instructor and students recognize this, therefore the difficulty is not like other Yale classes. However, the class still pushes students who are not particularly comfortable speaking in front of groups.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are in Naval ROTC, you will be required regardless to take this course. If you are a regular Yale student, then I recommend that you pass on this; spend your time on another leadership course at the school of management.
If you're taking this, you're required to.
